characters: WITH POISON PILL KLEIN. MAKE HIM PAY FOR PATRONIZING ME.
TO ATTENTION OF KLEIN. BRUSHED OFF. PRESS IN SPITE OF KLE
-HE'S A MATERIAL WITNESS TO A MURD-
SECRETED THE MURDER WEAPON WITH GEORGE AINGE. I HAVE ACQU
PUT THAT GOD DAMN GUN DOW-
KNIFE. IT IS A SIX-INCH BLADE WITH A MOTHER-OF-PEARL GRIP
NOONAN'S CAUSE. HIS PURPOSE IS PURE. DON'T WANT TO GET DR
SUSTAINED RIGHT THUMB AND RIGHT INDEX PRINTS WHICH MATCH
YOU ARE NOT BENT ON AN EX-WHORE
DUEL WITH A U.S. ATTORNEY MUCH LESS THE FBI. DEEP ADMIRAT
DAVE WEARING FORM-FITTING SHIRT TODAY. HANDSOME. I WANT T
WELLES NOONAN WILL WIN OUT. KLEIN NOT SKILLED OR SMART EN
COMPARISON POINTS TO FINGERPRINTS ON FILE FROM MISS BLEDS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stare at my broken face in a gilded mirror. The breaks occurred a lifetime ago, healed uneven. I wear a white tropical button-down, a Republican-gold Rolex, a pirate-p over what was my left eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm old. And all I have left is the will to remember... I reach into a dresser drawer, pull out a yellowed black white picture of HER: this beatific blonde, sleeping. Bel me is a week-old L.A. Times with the headline: Matriarch Television Series, Empire Ridge, Retires. The Matriarch's picture in the middle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and the fear I'll forget... Slide HER over the Matriarch's picture: the Matriarch 30 years younger now. Lift my eyes back to my reflection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I killed innocent men. I betrayed sacred oaths. I reaped profit from horror. The names are dead or too guilty to tell. The events so brutal they beg to be re-told... Legend: Los Angeles, Fall 1958

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The battered face of an Irish Pug. Same guy? No. A hard j bashes the Pug out of frame. And there I am: next to the `Ring' Magazine Reporter chewing the ass out of his cigar

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lieutenant Dave Klein, Vice Division. LAPD. That's what my face looked like before. My point of view now: Irish Pug on the business end of th bantam Black's combos. Standing to my left: SERGEANT RICH "JUNIOR" STEMMONS. Twenty-six.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Junior Stemmons. A partner I never asked for. The scowl meant to hide a shit-scared kid who'd been teaching evidence classes three months ago. His Old-Man was an LAPD lifer who never got past Sergeant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We should make our move now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mid-fight? Look at the crowd: you wanna be at the center of a riot?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't wanna be here when Noonan and the Feds show up. I point at the bantam Black:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We let Sanderline finish this beating, we get his gratitude.                          * Junior eyes the exits clockwise, nervous, waiting for `Untouchables' to break the doors down. I hate the way pa smells when I stand this close to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We gonna let Rock-a-bye fight too-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -relax Junior.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Bantam Black: SANDERLINE JOHNSON. Led through the dou doors. He sees me, then his gaze shifts to Junior popping jabs inches from REUBEN RUIZ: a muscled middle-weight, fi taped hands cuffed behind his back. I smile big:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sanderline, I'm Lieutenant Klein of the LAPD and a real big fan-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -you're under arrest. Sanderline spooks, steps back. Turn and make sure Junior the fire in my eyes, keep staring at Junior as I speak to Sanderline again:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No you're not. Reuben is-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -Lieutenant Dave why you arrest-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -for being a ranked fighter who still steals hubcaps. Shut up. (off Ruiz, back to Sanderline)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I was gonna arrest you, I wouldn't have let you finish: and that hook-uppercut combo you got is something special. (from Reuben, beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reuben's in custody. But you could be our Guest. Whaddya say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me, Junior, Reuben, and Sanderline aim for the nearest ex Behind the stands. Reuben and Sanderline in street clothe hats pulled down tight. Feature the Announcer:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ladies and Gentleman...due to circumstances beyond our control, Rock-A-Bye Ruiz will not fight this- -BOOS drown the PA. Beer and lit cigars shell the Announc Fights erupt in the stands. I can't stifle a chuckle. Thr exits down: day late-dollar short Feds. WELLES NOONAN, el out, surveying the scene like a half-assed Rommel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles Noonan, US Attorney. Ivy League Crimefighter. Launching a big boxing probe as a way to begin prying into everything else crooked and corrupt in LA. Move faster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unaware the LAPD was walking away with his two big witnesses. As we near the side exit I stop. Junior pauses, less than foot from my face, pointing up at Noonan, pure panic.

dialogues.speaker: C'MON-JESUS-HE'S RIGHT THERE
dialogues.text: My P.O.V.: second row, washed-up gangster Mickey Cohen wi Blonde far too beautiful for his world, a woman you've se before, but only in a yellowed B&W picture 30 years i future. I can't take my eyes away...five seconds-

dialogues.speaker: -HE SEES US
dialogues.text: Noonan's gaze strafes us. I see him squint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you can stop pointing at him. Double-time out the double-doors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 9th floor suite. All four of us. I order room service.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hungry Sanderline? Sanderline digs the digs: sports the Ambassador robe over street clothes, reading the Bible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If they got shrimp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into the phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shrimp cocktail. (over to Reuben)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want something Reuben?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To know why the fuck I'm here-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -mind your tone, Shitbird...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shitbird went out with Vaudeville. You get your badge in a cereal box?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're here because we want you to remember where you live.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SANDERLINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grade-school mind) City of Angels. ME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excellent Sanderline. REUBEN RUIZ

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? ME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You live in LA, Asshole. You do not live in `Federal Government.' Ruiz turns `caught-me' pink...I nod to Junior: split `em. Playing adjoining hotel rooms like sweat boxes. JUNIOR STEMMONS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We get to spend time alone now. REUBEN RUIZ

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want some perfume? Junior shoves Ruiz through the inner-door connecting the rooms. Sanderline giggles. Close the door behind them. Si down inches from Sanderline, change my tone: ME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop laughing. Instant quiet. ME (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What were you gonna tell Welles Noonan? (watch as he flinches) He has a subpoena with your name on it, Sanderline. Why would someone like you need to talk to the U.S. Attorney? Sanderline staying silent... ME (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a legbreaker for the Mob. I know the Men that pay you for that will murder you if they hear you're about to talk to the U.S.- SANDERLINE JOHNSON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -but they don't know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat, small smile) And they don't have to. Now tell me what you were gonna tell Noonan- -phone rings. Sanderline flinches for the second time. SANDERLINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bet you they ran outta shrimp. I stand, step, answer it: ME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. UNIDENTIFIED VOICE (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Spook with you? Mild shock. Catalogue potential "who's"... UNIDENTIFIED VOICE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, we know he is. We're just trying to be mysterious- ME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -who's `we?' UNIDENTIFIED VOICE (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me and Sam G. ME (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: G for `Giancana.' I owe him favors for the rest of my life. UNIDENTIFIED VOICE (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're out at the place in Palm Springs. You should come out for the weekend. ME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell Sam if I get minute- UNIDENTIFIED VOICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -yer gonna have to make a minute for him. Now. See, we think the Spade might testify that Sam owns him and how we was grooming him for a title shot he was gonna tank. A fight everybody woulda' got flush off of, including the Spade.                        * (beat, quieter) Have him look out the window Klein.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Click. A breath. Drop the phone on the cradle...step to t window...open it...then I chuckle genuine:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sanderline, you gotta see this... Trusting puppy Sanderline steps to the window:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'm I- -smash his head against the frame using his forward motio He loses muscle control for the split-second it takes me pitch his legs up and out. My face a quick-change evil ma Feature Sanderline's nine-story fall. That Ambassador Hot robe billows behind him like a cape. He detonates an over streetlight with a bomb sound, then hits the driveway. Unzip my fly, hustle into the bathroom, screams from outs now. Flush the toilet as Junior and Ruiz pile through the door. Step out, play it baffled: look at the bed where Sanderline sat, then the open window, screams floating up

dialogues.speaker: DID THAT MUTT JUST JUMP
dialogues.text: Lunge to the window: Sanderline post-mortem. Head shatter Valets sprinting. Junior on the phone. Ruiz steps-up next me: horrified. I keep staring at the smashed body...whisp

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember where you live. Reuben has to use both hands to steady himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spartan space appointed with high-ticket items like the mahogany table around which we sit. Outside: echoes of a protest filter through the windows:

dialogues.speaker: DODGERS NO
dialogues.text: Four of us at the table glued to the T.V, watching U.S. Attorney Welles Noonan lambasting the LAPD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LA's version of the Young Turks, only meaner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ME (V.O.) (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boyce Bradley, Chief of Detectives. Smartest man in town. And one of the richest: Dad was a Real Estate Developer who owned a strip of land that's now known as the Santa Monica Freeway. On either side, Bradley's book-ends: D.A. Bob Gallaudet, not the smartest man in town: `Gas Chamber' Bob cribbed my notes at USC Law. And Tom Bethune, running for a City Council seat that'll decide if this Mexican slum called Chavez Ravine gets bulldozed and renamed `Dodger Stadium.'              * BRADLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turn it off. Bethune leaps like a lapdog, hits the power. ME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was pissing. He was jumping. Bradley picks up a newspaper: BRADLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: `US Attorney Noonan is accusing the Los Angeles Police Department in general, and Lt. David Klein in particular, of murder at worst, gross incompetence at best...' ME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Noonan had Sanderline scared. After he sang to me he panicked & jumped. TOM BETHUNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He did spend a month in Camarillo Mental Hospital last year- GAS CHAMBER BOB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -and wearing that hotel robe over his clothes makes him look even more looney-bin. TOM BETHUNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Plus, Reuben Ruiz recanted. So Noonan's Boxing Probe is dead. He's got nothing- BRADLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -but time, a mandate and new targets...I need to speak to the Lieutenant alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob and Tom nod, pat my back on the way out: proud uncles lending support before Dad drops the hammer. Door closes. stand, step to the window, big Pro-Mex protest below: Gee and placards: `BASEBALL IS AS AMERICAN AS THE TRAIL OF TE BRADLEY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Describe to me your duty, as you understood it, regarding Sanderline Johnson and Reuben Ruiz. ME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take both men into custody before Noonan and the Feds could, and find                   * out what they were going to tell- BRADLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -and why did I choose you for this? ME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I'm a Cop with a law degree, and you thought my legal- BRADLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -because your a thug with a law degree. Because I thought by now you'd be so indebted to this Department for not indicting and/or                   * imprisoning you, that diligent, honest discharge of duty would be assured. (beat) And I made a horrible misjudgment.                    * ME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bethune and Gallaudet don't think so. BRADLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob's happy because he wants to be State Attorney General and his most likely opponent will be Welles Noonan. Tom's happy because Morton Diskant, who's leading their City Council race, is endorsed by Noonan. Thus, they're not seeing the larger play. (with calculated emphasis) Noonan's new target will likely be the LAPD itself. ME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRADLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because that's where I would aim: a subpoenaed Federal witness plummets to his death in the company of two LAPD detectives? (beat) This screams Police Corruption.                      * This offers Noonan the possibility of payback in the form of national headlines. I wave it all off: ME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnson did that stint at the Nut House -- leak his file to your friends at the times- -and Bradley drops his bomb: Coroner's file. I stare...gu the contents...try to keep my heart rate in-check... BRADLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My friends would be more interested in this. (beat, flipping file open) Coroner's preliminary: white paint chips found embedded in Sanderline Johnson's scalp. A matching dent on the white window sill. I checked with the hotel switchboard and found a call was patched to your room at about the same time Johnson flew out of it. (beat, proclamation:) It shocks and sickens me that your allegiance to the Chicago mob would take precedence over the LAPD. ME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fuck drawing this out) Alright. Where's this going?                         * (pull my badge, table it) Gun? Shield? What? BRADLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The appearance of disciplinary measures taken against you are mandated post-Sanderline Johnson,                    * so your suspension will be recorded but sealed...and kept quiet for now-                 *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So if the papers or Noonan come sniffing around- BRADLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -we can provide adequate proof of your dismissal. ME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you're not dismissing me. BRADLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just on paper. (closes the file) Since I misjudged the Cop I thought you were, I'm going to leverage the Cop that you are. Bradley slides the morning paper over. Front page: `Candi Diskant Hears The Hue and Cry of The Underclass...' The p shows a smiling Diskant, rolled shirt-sleeves, in the mid of a sea of LA Immigrants, all smiling back. BRADLEY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morton Diskant is to be removed from the City Council race. The means and methods implemented to that end I will entrust to you. ME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (throw a thumb at Bethune) You want me to torpedo Diskant so your buddy Bethune can win a City                      * Council seat uncontested- BRADLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -or spend the next month in lock-up                    * before being arraigned on charges                      * of gross misconduct and dereliction                    * of duty. The preamble before you                       * face life in prison for murder.                        * I stare back. Feel myself getting fitted for strings... BRADLEY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Diskant works Saturdays. Late. Bradley waves me out. I intentionally drag my badge back across the desk, scratching his Mahogany heirloom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hollywood Hills loom in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bradley's stooge now. A smart play suspending me: a built-in shield                        * for him if things go sideways. Traffic teeming up Fairfax, tourettes-like glances in my view...a Black Buick...maybe mirroring my lane changes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Black Buick...five Cars back...feels like a tail... Brake hard. They hang a left on Fountain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...or maybe I just need sleep. Cruising up Nichols Canyon to the pad, cameras and copywriters loom on my front lawn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Press camped out post-Sanderline, looking for quotes to hang me with.                     * Slouch in the seat, accelerate, keep looking back...dig t geek from the Hearld pissing in my hedges.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up the walkway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Retreat to Meg's. My kid sister and only living family. Mom and Pop died in `51 when their first plane ride became their last. Scoop Meg's LA Herald of the ground. Headlines condemn me Tuck it under my arm as Meg opens the door:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glances from paper to me)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I already got the Times inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silver tea-pot over blue flame on olive-drab stove. The T open on the table between us...Same shitty headlines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much is true?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many times have I lied to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zero. Shrug. Play aloof. Hope it suffices.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've always liked your Men mean. She looks up at me. Feels the shame I shun...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What would Mom and Dad say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. That's where I learned it. She stands, goes to the stove.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poor you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, pour me...a cup please. Black, no sugar. Meg stares darts. I smile to defuse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty please. She fetches cups and saucers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's work?                                             *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's Pete?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More work. Quiet while we wait for the pot...and quiet always means creeping sleep: an Enemy I never stop fighting. Force my open, shift in my seat: I've been exhausted for years. I drift despite my best efforts and for a split second yo see the Hell I see when sleep wins:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fire where the clouds should be -- POP -- in a backseat, point-blank Tommy-gunning two smiling men -- POP -- Marin fatigues soaked in blood, plunging my bayonet into a cheesecake-white belly -- POP -- that beautiful blonde fr the Olympic, smiling -- POP-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -awake. My leg jerks, kicks a big Wing-Tip. A cup of coff pipes in front of me. Then voices. I turn: PETE BONDURANT his hands on my sister's shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big Pete Bondurant. One-time LA Sheriff. Bounced when he beat-dead a Prisoner who spit at him. A duly impressed Howard Hughes hired him on as his full-time muscle. My Sister's new Hump. My oldest living Friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turns back at me)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look like Death taking a shit. Meg cackles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's still got that MGM-face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're still the only guy who ever traded movie-potential for Police work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because in the movies they make you pull your punches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drain my mug. To Pete:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wanna do LAPD a favor tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. We're going to the Cocoanut- -Pete puts an extended index finger in front of Meg's lip which she bends backwards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Favor' mean `free?'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Means $500 an hour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gimme the phone so I can find another Date-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -you're the only Woman I know who calls Men-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -you're the only Man I know who doesn't call Women. Pete laughs, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are we doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me and Junior in the car. Pete street-side, tucked into t shadows -- mimes jacking off, checks his watch. Everybody bored. Glance again at the file in my lap:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morton Diskant, a man who preferred migrant workers to million dollar ballparks. Beating Bethune in their City Council Race despite getting outspent 10 to 1. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he wins, the Dodgers don't get a Stadium, Mexicans get to keep raising chickens two miles from City Hall and Bradley makes sure I                   * burn for Sanderline Johnson.                         *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Junior in the backseat, penning in a steno, mouthing something to himself. ME (V.O.) (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Junior brought along because he begged. Already hip to how many ways you can make money with a badge. JUNIOR STEMMONS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a birthday coming up. ME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? JUNIOR STEMMONS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the 16th, right? How old? ME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Old. What are you writing?                          * Head down, scribbling mid-sentence, makes me wait a beat. JUNIOR STEMMONS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just notes...about work- ME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -what `work'? JUNIOR STEMMONS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mostly compare and contrast stuff. Street work versus textbook- ME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -chapter 1: don't write shit down. Chapter 2: or other Cops might kill                 * you. Junior's look practiced in a mirror: clicks the pen, slid the steno away. JUNIOR STEMMONS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you think Noonan will come after you for the Sanderline thing? He seems like a real hard charger. Bait him, see if he bites. ME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (the deadest deadpan) I heard he was coming after both of us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Feature real concern from Junior.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indictments. Prison time. Whole nine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holy Jesus. Is this true?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm seriously thinking about turning Junior...testifying against you. Junior goes sour...gets he's being goosed. I laugh, glanc out the windshield: see Diskant finally exiting the offic

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here we go. I start the car, slow-roll up the street. My Hamilton say 11:04 PM. Streets deserted. Pete walking in Diskant's direction now as I continue to roll toward both. Pete clo dig his giant head nodding `hello.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seen Pete do this a dozen times and every time the same thought: Pete suddenly puts his back into an left hook: hammers Diskant from nowhere as they pass. Instant-ugly crumble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God help me if he ever hits me like that. Pete hoists Diskant by his waist-band, tosses him in the backseat. I accelerate out, obeying every law.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PITCH BLACK. Then a series of strobe-flashbulbs: maybe fl maybe two bodies, maybe both hairy/pale. Then groaning, t flickering fluorescent lights make it all look jaundiced.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lights now. Diskant awake, trying to loosen his jaw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ME (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Junior picked up this Quiff jocking other Fags in a Men's Room. But Quiff was a Law Student who wanted his record kept clean. Quiff nervous but cooing, dick out, on Diskant's thigh. Junior just as nervous...reloading a camera. JUNIOR STEMMONS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He should suck his dick. Y'know? Put the icing on it. A baffled moment as the comment registers. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? JUNIOR STEMMONS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me that wouldn't sell it...plus he's a Communist. ME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're ruining his career, not his soul. Reload the camera. Diskant finally speaks: marble-mouthed. Pushes Quiff away MORTON DISKANT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Off me! Don't waste a second: grab Diskant by the hair, narrate h immediate future. ME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drop out of the City Council race or I send these pictures to the papers. Diskant rips his head free. Rage. Blood from his mouth. Scanning the room, sizing up the situation, then: MORTON DISKANT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll fight you rotten- ME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -and maybe salvage something that's a close cousin to `respect.' But what about your wife and kid getting hold of those pictures?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait for the big futile scream/struggle. Keep waiting. Diskant just sits. No words. And now I wish he'd cry, thr punches, anything...but he doesn't. I turn to Junior:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take the Quiff home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name's Franklin-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -of course it is. Junior pulls Quiff out the door. By his hand. Just Pete, and Diskant now. Silent moments drag sour...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need a nod from you Morton, let's me know you get it-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -don't say my name...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone from the Times will call for a quote. Whatever your reason for dropping out make it real. As Pete and I turn to leave:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not looking at us)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You eventually lose the ability to reconcile the things you've done to people. That's Hell. A long moment on me and Pete. Blunted by what we just hea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete driving. Silence. Tune to an all-night Jazz signal, up the volume loud enough to jumble doubts. Toss Pete his cut. A $500 roll.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pocketing the money)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y'know Hughes has a job you're tailor-made for. I already gave him your-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -no thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop pretending you're not a pig for all this, Klein.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I still got a day job, Pete-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -tossing more Bantamweights out                       * windows? I wait too long, answer in too high a voice:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Mutt jumped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs small, then:)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not even the people who don't know you believe that. If somebody from the DA's office decides to dig, you could fry Boy-o. Be nice to be in with a billionaire who's got a fleet of planes, fly you outta the country on a moment's notice. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon -- it's a cake legal gig. He                    * just wants you to burn some actress that stopped fucking him. Stop in front of Meg's place. Pete leaves the engine runn jumps out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow. Hughes Aircraft, 7pm                        * It'll be worth it. I watch Pete go into Meg's place. Drive on. Stop sign. A block away: Black Buick parallel to me. Exhaust plumes. L they're waiting. I keep my eyes on the rear-view as I pass...but it just stays put...idling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lights off but something grabs my eye instantly. Kitchen table: a manila envelope. 100 $100-bills. USC season tick A note: `Thanks for proving Flying Monkeys only live in O Sam G.' Exhale. Flip to the same jazz station. Sit. Start another futile fight with sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The last thing I see before I nod black: my War Trophy, a Japanese Officer's Samurai Sword mounted on my mantle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Artillery barrages from Hell: Okinawa, 1945. A hate-fuele frenzy hacking up half-starved Jap Soldiers. They dive of the Cliffs to escape me: this massive, gray-eyed Marine. I dive after them. Bombing toward a world below already ablaze. Falling. Gaining on a figure in a bathrobe. This guttural scream turns mechanical, like a ring as I recogn Sanderline Johnson: his pieced-together face smiling up. awake. My phone ringing. 1 AM. Rip the phone from the wal

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Klein-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -you know who Hector Magdalena is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as cobwebs clear)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...yeah...Narco's Snitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's missing. His home was broken into at some point within the last hour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So send Robbery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The only thing taken was him. Wilshire Station is on-scene. Get over there right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call it penance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought that's what Morton Diskant was-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -that makes one of us. 1284 South Tremaine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRADLEY (cont'd) (edge to his voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This kind of timing makes for disasters, Lieutenant. I hear the first split-second of Bradley smashing his pho down. Click my own cradle. Wipe my face. Dial another num

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Junior. Meet me at 1284 South                         * Tremaine. 20 minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Police abound. Mostly work-a-day Blues pounding coffee. T part as I approach: Dave "Enforcer" Klein half-legend her plain-clothes breaks through, aims right at me: DAN WILHI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain Dan Wilhite, Head of the LAPD Narcotics Division. A Michigan Catholic poisoned by 25 years in this desert. Recently divorced despite seven kids with his Ex.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You smell like bourbon Wilhite-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -fuck off. This is handled. And pull your idiot partner out of there-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -Junior's already here-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -Magdalena was my Snitch, so it's my scene. -push past him, toward the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then get Bradley on the horn, so you can relay that order. I'm here on his word. Now, what happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dragged out of him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guard dogs are dead. Magdalena's missing.

dialogues.speaker: ME
dialogues.text: And presumed what?

dialogues.speaker: WILHITE
dialogues.text: I could give a shit. I just want to this case to get a quick burial.

dialogues.speaker: ME
dialogues.text: I'll bet. Who made the call?

dialogues.speaker: WILHITE
dialogues.text: Some old broad heard an `argument' and buzzed Wilshire Station.                *

dialogues.speaker: ME
dialogues.text: Where's the family?

dialogues.speaker: WILHITE
dialogues.text: The wife and daughter were in Santa Barbara. Just got back.

dialogues.speaker: ME
dialogues.text: (check my Hamilton) At 2 AM?                                    *

dialogues.speaker: WILHITE
dialogues.text: The Wife said she got into a fight          * with her Parents, left ASAP.                *

dialogues.speaker: ME
dialogues.text: Why wasn't Hector with `em?                 *

dialogues.speaker: WILHITE
dialogues.text: What do you think they were                 * fighting about? Santa Barbara Wasps         * don't fancy dope-pushing Wetbacks.

dialogues.speaker: ME
dialogues.text: What about the Son?                         *

dialogues.speaker: WILHITE
dialogues.text: (sneering hatred) Tommy. Make him your #1 suspect.

dialogues.speaker: ME
dialogues.text: Why's that?                                 *

dialogues.speaker: WILHITE
dialogues.text: He's got a mean streak. And he and          * Hector had been at each others throats for months. Have Tommy              * picked up. He likes to loaf at              * those nigger jazz joints in Watts.          *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright, you better cut out before                      * people start asking why the head of Narco is at a missing persons. Wilhite gets close, still sneering:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get a conviction. Grab Tommy and pin this thing fast or you'll have a whole division of disgraced cops at your front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about Wilhite?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You queered the Fed's   Fight Probe by killing that boxer   and they already had a hard-on   for the LAPD-                   * Bradley sent you down   here as damaged goods...think   about it. Everybody sees what's   coming. (beat, closer)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now close this quick. Wilhite bolts. I pause. Clarity finally dissolving the bloodshot: this is the disaster Bradley was talking about

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The God-sized problems I triggered tossing Sanderline take shape: the LAPD's sanctioned dope-pusher vanishes -- that's a pretty juicy                       * spot to stick a new probe.                              *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All money, no taste. In the foyer: a Wilshire Station six pack interviews the old BIDDIE in a threadbare bathrobe. orange hair and a burnt-butter grin. Leans-lunges as she relays her story. I zoom in to catch the performance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mid-sentence)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -shifty...colored...y'know Negros are planning an invasion! After our white women and our water supply-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -where was this Peeper you saw?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BIDDIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bushes. Spyin' on Lucille. Seen him                   * there before! He's a black saboteur                   * looking for fertile white wombs. Wanna breed a mulatto master race-                    * -cut into the crazy:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Officer. The Six-Pack crosses to confer. ME (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Besides bat-shit insanity, is there anything else about her that rings true? OFFICER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heard an argument, loud, maybe a minute or two, then silence. ME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this `Peeper' riff she's on? OFFICER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She saw someone in the bushes earlier. She's reported that kind of thing a dozen other times. She's also reported flying saucers, so... ME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See if any of the other Neighbors can verify this `Peeper' thing.                       * Roam. A hallway. Junior the grim-faced professional, He's that damn steno out, scribbling like he's on a deadline. JUNIOR STEMMONS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one touch a thing `til I say. He's hovering over a lake of blood, drag marks originatin that lake lead out to the garage. Junior sees me. See him startle, then jut his tough-guy chin on reflex:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave- ME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -Lieutenant Klein. I said `meet me' in twenty minutes' not `go in without me.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUNIOR STEMMONS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All I've been doing- ME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hard/harsh/low) -is stepping on dicks. You don't know the history, the players or the play. Pull Junior aside, impart the following tightly: ME (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Department gave Magdalena a                      * monopoly on the LA dope trade decades ago- JUNIOR STEMMONS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -what Department? ME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Us Pollyanna -- LAPD. We bullet- proofed him in exchange for 60% of his profit and a promise he only deal drugs in Darktown and East LA-                  * JUNIOR STEMMONS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -Black and Mexican- ME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -give the man a prize. He'd also                     * rat his competition and kill the ones we couldn't convict. Now keep your mouth shut and stay on my hip. JUNIOR STEMMONS                            *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine.                                                * I want to bounce his head off the wall. I continue my tou instead. Follow the blood-trail out into the garage where ends in another smaller lake of blood. JUNIOR STEMMONS (CONT'D)                   *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loaded him into a car- ME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -are all the Magdalena vehicles accounted for? JUNIOR STEMMONS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Except for the Son's: Tommy.                         *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Continue the tour. Kitchen. Two Dobermans, shot dead. Fea matching bullet wounds right between their eyes -- yell t the Officer with the Biddie: ME

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER.
dialogues.text: As he pokes his head around the corner: ME (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old lady hear dogs barking?                       * Gunshots? OFFICER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I asked. Just the yelling. Examine the wounds closer. Catch myself petting the decea pooches. To Junior: ME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She didn't hear barking...so they were either lousy guard dogs...or they knew the Killer. (point to the wounds) You can't hit something this clean unless you're point blank. He could've been petting them when he fired: look at the burn pattern-                      * (point) Like when you shoot something with a silencer. JUNIOR STEMMONS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know that? ME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stare so he gets it) I've shot things with silencers... And the old lady didn't hear any                      * gunshots. JUNIOR STEMMONS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You make a family member for it? Tommy? ME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe...                                              * JUNIOR STEMMONS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want to issue an APB?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to talk to Bradley first. Where are the Mother and Daughter?                   *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Feature this old Matriarch hanging by the thinnest thread MADGE MAGDALENA, fifty-plus, dyed blonde bouffant pulled and picked. Sad clown tears smearing too much mascara. Sh pitches a boo-hoo in between belts of wine to a bored sti Wilshire Station six-pack. LUCILLE MAGDALENA, 20's: Daughter. Big bedroom eyes. A to two sizes too tight. Pops a palm of pills. Doesn't look t shattered about Daddy's demise. I make eye contact. I cat bruises on her arms. She sees me see, tries to cover nonchalant. The wall phone rings. Grab without asking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Klein.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Update.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hector's gone. Blood that may or may not be his leads out to the                      * garage. Two guard dogs shot dead but no other signs of a struggle. The house is intact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Family?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wife and Daughter are here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Describe their state.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother Madge aggrieved.                              * (aim my gaze at Lucille)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daughter Lucille...indifferent. The                  * son is persona non grata and a strong early suspect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright, kick everyone out. Including all police personnel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't question me. Is your partner on hand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah...                                               *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have him bag and seal everything and bring it to Wilshire Station. Find Tommy Magdalena post-haste and take him into custody. No APB's, nothing to alert Noonan and the FBI to this situation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want me to-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -no more information over an open                     * line. I'll be at the Bethune event later on today. Find me there. Click. Second time he's hung up on me in an hour. Pull Ju to me just as he's going through a stack of mail:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm giving you on-scene command.                      * Bradley wants everyone removed from the premises and the entire house bagged for evidence and brought to Wilshire Station. (more of a dare)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you handle this? Big brown-nose nods from an aim-to-please Junior.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Entirely. Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To find Tommy Magdalena.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rolling up Hollywood to Highland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big yawns. Half haze from no sleep. Buzz dispatch. A message from Pete. `Reminder: Hughes aircraft, 7 PM.                      * Glance street-side: Sanderline smiling blood in a wind bl bathrobe. Blink and he's gone, replaced by a kid hawking Times. Pull-over. Toss the kid a coin. Front page: LEADING CANDI BOWS FROM CITY COUNCIL RACE, next to a picture of Diskant Pissed for reasons I won't name. Back to the Car. A Black Buick passes, slower than the rest of traffic, act like I oblivious. It turns. I slide in, start my Pontiac.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another Black Buick. Call it a Fed                     * Tail. Noonan already up my ass.                        * (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's see if they got guts enough to keep following me South.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cruising the Crenshaw district, up through Central Ave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dispatch gave me Tommy's make and model: A `32 Ford Deuce with a bent eight. Hot-rodder Tommy liked to goose the cops into giving chase. Check my mirrors. That Black Buick hangs way back. Cruise past jazz clubs: The Savoy, Joe Morris's Plantation, Shep Playhouse, the Down Beat...no sign of a Ford Deuce. Pull to the Club Alabam. Valets stare: a white man in Watts at this hour can only be Cop. Park. Half-a-block back: buzzcuts in that black Buick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Noonan tail confirmed: Fed faces                       * glow like Martians this far down Crenshaw. Smile big, give `em a thumbs-up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barely sober patrons sport Cop-hate stares, some on refle some because of Sanderline Johnson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doorman escort the bewildered, strong-arm the belligerent Almost 6 AM and the club is still half full. Press on, scan the stage: A Bebop trio toils over an Erro Garner tune as a beautiful black girl sings in a satin so lilt. This whispering falsetto that makes your hair stand end. I stop and listen. Get my only smile of the day from her. Smile back because her voice reminds me to. Hear beer bottles rattle behind and break. Turn. Squeeze smile into a sneer, stare down this massive BARTENDER. ME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flop badge on bar) Get Lester and get me a scotch                        * straight.                                             * The bartender glowers, grabs a bottle, pours, hands the s of catcher's mitts. He slides the glass. I sip. BARTENDER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sanderline Johnson was my second                      * cousin, Peckerwood. I wouldn't                        * drink that with my gun hand. He vanishes behind a stained curtain. Feel those voodoo stares from behind...and I switch the scotch glass to my hand as nonchalant as possible. Bartender reappears, moti me back. I follow. Backstage. I see a figure stretched pr ice-pack pressed to his face, rolled reefer between his l ME (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lester Lake. One-time velvet voiced crooner. But a dabble in the dope trade cost him a set of slashed vocal cords at the hands of none                      * other than Hector Magdalena.                          * Only as I get closer do I see the badly swollen black eye looks up at me. A voice like sand-paper left out in the s LESTER LAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lieutenant Dave Klein. Slayer of                      * Sanderline Johnson...y'got stones                     * showing up this far South.                            * ME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened to your face? LESTER LAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) Tommy Mag wanted to make sure I understood something he was saying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is he? LESTER LAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Left an hour ago. Emptied my safe. ME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit. He's wise. LESTER LAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To what? You looking for him? Lester hands me the reefer, take it, toke geeky, belch sm ME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (at the reefer) Just never got this... Lester takes it back, draws deep. LESTER LAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too white to appreciate good grass.                   * Now watch Lester's attitude improve toot sweet: ME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hector Magdalena is missing, presumed dead. Tommy is our sole suspect. He spurts smoke, sits up like a shot, beams. LESTER LAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Muthafucker -- there is a God. If only I'd known this an hour ago. ME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heartbreaker, huh? You let him gig here last night? LESTER LAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't let him, he just does. Nails on a chalkboard too. He rushed the stage last week when we had Charlie Mingus drop in for a set. Mingus looked at this half-Mex                   * greaser kid trying to play `Round                     * Midnight,' said that fool couldn't                    * find them keys with a flashlight.' ME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tommy's playing days are over.

dialogues.speaker: LESTER LAKE
dialogues.text: Hallelujah.

dialogues.speaker: ME
dialogues.text: What time did he show up?

dialogues.speaker: LESTER LAKE
dialogues.text: Around four. Him and these Pachucos         * poppin' switchblades like punks. (mops his brow of blood) The only thing that was keepin' him         * `untouched' was Hector...                   * (beat, hopeful-prayer) Is he really dead?                          *

dialogues.speaker: ME
dialogues.text: There's blood all over his house, seems to belong to him. There's just no body. Not yet.

dialogues.speaker: LESTER LAKE
dialogues.text: (a toke, a thought) I don't feature Tommy for it.               *

dialogues.speaker: ME
dialogues.text: (my head kinks a bit)                   * How's that? How many times has he           * been in here, busted you up?

dialogues.speaker: LESTER LAKE
dialogues.text: Yeah, but he ain't got the salt             * to truly take a Man's life.                 * Especially not Hector's...he was            * scared of him.                              *

dialogues.speaker: ME
dialogues.text: Why?                                        *

dialogues.speaker: LESTER LAKE
dialogues.text: `Cuz Hector been whippin' Tommy's           * ass from the time he could talk.            *

dialogues.speaker: ME
dialogues.text: What about the Wife? Beat her too?          *

dialogues.speaker: LESTER LAKE
dialogues.text: We used to call that old bitch `the         * Burglar'...eyes were so black, it           * looked like she had a mask on.              *

dialogues.speaker: ME
dialogues.text: And the daughter? Lucille?                  *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lester can't quip that one as quick. Tokes. Shaking his h LESTER LAKE                                 *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Things up off the street. Rumors.                     *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like?                                                 * LESTER LAKE                                 *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hector had turned her out. Using                      * her the way the Romans used to use                    * their daughters when they did                         * business: Some pussy to sweeten the                   * pot. Rumor was she got picked up in                   * this trick sweep few weeks back.                      * ME                                          *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hector was whoring her?                               * LESTER LAKE                                 *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hector was an evil Muthafucker.                       * ...Lester tilts his neck back, points to a long keloid sc that stretches across his throat... LESTER LAKE (CONT'D)                        *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...born with ruthless bones.                          * (sitting up)                                      * And if he really is dead and gone,                    * this game `bout to explode.                           *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What game?                                            * LESTER LAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drugs. Especially here in South Central. Hector ran it uncontested. Lotta cats gonna rush in now, try to plant a flag.                                      * ME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tommy can't hold the throne?                          * LESTER LAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tommy couldn't hold his pecker without Hector's help and he knows                    * that. He's gonna bury himself like                    * a tick. Good luck turning him up,                     * he took six or seven grand out the                    * safe tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eyes and ears for me Lester. He turns up, you get in touch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I don't kill him first.                              *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bethune Campaign Fundraiser turned Victory Bash. Big smil beam above sunburned double-chins. Bethune the nucleus of Press circle-jerk. I weave around, lack of sleep and a miserably wrinkled suit make me look like something dug u

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Councilman Bethune, was Mr. Diskant dropping out the only way you could have won this race?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not at all. My message of civic advancement manifested in that beautiful blue baseball team was starting to hit home. Bethune's beam twitches when he sees me weaving past. Giv him a quick nod, get nothing back: he can't be seen this close to the turd in the punch bowl. Moving by:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything you'd like to say to future constituents?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like my Dodger Dogs with mustard and relish! Bradley at one of the front tables confabbing with DA Gas Chamber Bob Gallaudet. As I aim their way, one of my favo men aims at me, wearing this Great White grin: FRITZ KOEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fritz Koenig. German born. Former                       * US Spymaster, current Head of the                       * LAPD's Intelligence Division. He                        * and Bradley in the middle of their own Cold War -- each fighting to be the second most important member of                     * the LAPD behind Chief Parker.                           *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KOENIG                              *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These functions aren't normally               * open to Jews.                                 * ME                                  *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone with your accent should               * never be allowed to say `Jew'                 * again.                                        * KOENIG                              *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That accent allowed me to execute             * many a Nazi.                                  * ME                                  *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then we're both Traitors: Ellis               * Island said Grandpa's `Kleinsasser'           * was two syllables too long.                   * KOENIG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't have expected so public a showing after Sanderline Johnson. ME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He jumped Fritz. Koenig flashes that grin again. KOENIG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure he did. And where is your young partner this day? ME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Working his first big job. KOENIG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Might the job involve the LAPD's most important missing Wetback, Hector Magdalena? My eyes narrow but stay smiling: ME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It does. Koenig nods, casts his gaze out over the crowd. KOENIG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've known Stemmons since the academy. He was a top pupil. A                * peculiar little pain in the ass, but very good with details.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kid might have some climb in him. (look back at Bradley) Reminds me of another pain in the ass. Koenig roars this big frightening laugh of his. KOENIG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm puzzled as to why the Bradley would assign you to the Magdalena                     * case when you're neither Homicide nor Robbery... ME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no body, and nothing was taken except Hector. KOENIG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He does know how to delegate doesn't he...and also I'm sure that poor Negro's nosedive has put you squarely in his debt. ME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something like that.                                  * KOENIG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep me abreast will you? Chief Parker is understandably nervous. Situations like these tend to yield grief...and we've the FBI poking                      * around our garden patch.                              * ME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My ass first Fritz, yours second. Koenig's big laugh again. Moving toward Bradley now. Then flashbulbs pop-blind. Panic: snapping pix of me? Relief: me. Hollywood types: this Buff McMan Meat-type and Her. I slack inches from the Press that yesterday wanted to roll my guts...but now they're just as entranced with her as I She and McMan Meat continue past as I stare, she answers questions for him. I think her eyes see mine. Then I real where I'm standing. Bradley waiting. Focused on me and no her -- God-damned Eunuch. I step over, speak without pref ME (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tommy Magdalena has gone to ground and he's got a war chest to keep him there. The only way we take him quickly is to issue a citywide APB-

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: -no. We can't risk that. Do you             * make him for the murderer?

dialogues.speaker: ME
dialogues.text: Yeah. Hector's disappearance is definitely an inside job. That whole family feels hinky. The daughter was all bruises and no tears and Hector's hop-head wife            * looks part punching bag.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: Do you suspect either of the women?         *

dialogues.speaker: ME
dialogues.text: According to Wilhite, they were in Santa Barbara at the time.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: Verify that. Where is your partner?

dialogues.speaker: ME
dialogues.text: Vouching in evidence at Wilshire Station.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: Keep him on that. He had excellent ratings as an evidence teacher and          * I trust him more than you. (beat) Find Tommy Magdalena. Focus everything on that effort & I want him apprehended Klein, not killed.

dialogues.speaker: ME
dialogues.text: What about Hector? Still missing.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: And most likely dead. Find the Son.         * Stakeout the residence. Put tails on both the mother and daughter -- I want this investigation working quietly, and around the clock.

dialogues.speaker: ME
dialogues.text: And what do we do if Hector turns           * up?                                         *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRADLEY                                    *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he's alive, bring him to me. If he's dead, have him John Doe'd at                    * the morgue until Noonan can be                       * drawn off and this FBI situation                     * sorted out.                                          * ME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wilhite. He was operating Hector- BRADLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -don't worry about Dan Wilhite. You deal directly with me. Now go out the back. I don't want the press recognizing you. Swallow my sneer. Push through the service doors. Hard. Headed back toward the kitchen, an exit sign. I pass an alcove: Her. Alone. Smoke break. Beauty you almost never to examine up close. I stop, stammer, she gives me a once over, thinks I'm a Reporter... ME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a light? WOMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (searches my empty hands) You got a cigarette? I fumble for a Chesterfield. She pulls a Zippo slow. WOMAN (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you snap a picture of me, I get to set you on fire. Fair? I smile too wide -- fuck. I kill it, try to gather up the bits of `cool' that shattered with the sophomore smile. ME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It didn't look like you were all that upset with the attention. WOMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good thing you're not a cop. ME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) How's that? WOMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your power of observation leaves lots to be desired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lights my cigarette. I hold it in my mouth to hide shakin hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't thank me: these things are bad for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You believe everything you read? Stubs her cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You believe anything you read? She starts walking back the way I came.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hail-mary)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you eat Dinner?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I can't stop watching her, even after she pushes back thr the double doors, re-entering the fray head-first. I step after her. A reporter finally makes me. Random catcalls o `Klein! `Hey, Enforcer!' Shutterbugs beeline my way, firi flashbulbs from the hip. Close the door quick and bolt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make a note: steal Bethune's guest-                     * list, then go door-to-door until                        * you find her again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stroll. Sidelong stares on the periphery. Muted whispers desk cops. Feature this rookie chump clear a path as I pa Down a flight of stairs to the evidence lockers. Junior writes seizure abstracts, sealing materials in green-band evidence bags. A pile stacked neatly on the table next to him. That red steno pad in full view.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This everything from the house? A beat. He makes me wait as he finishes writing.

dialogues.speaker: JUNIOR STEMMONS
dialogues.text: Everything worthwhile.

dialogues.speaker: ME
dialogues.text: What did you tell the Watch Commander upstairs?

dialogues.speaker: JUNIOR STEMMONS
dialogues.text: (schoolboy proud) That this was a random drug seizure. I'm not using names and I'm number coding everything. A load of interesting stuff too. (points to each stack) I got unregistered fire-arms, more dope than I've ever seen, and some mail from business associates that seems hinky. We should follow up-           * (grabs an envelope)                     * -here, this one, `Hurwitz Holdings'         * Hector had some real estate dealings-

dialogues.speaker: ME
dialogues.text: -bag it until Bradley orders us otherwise.

dialogues.speaker: JUNIOR STEMMONS
dialogues.text: (like I'm speaking Greek)               * How do you solve a case when the evidence is in bags?

dialogues.speaker: ME
dialogues.text: You don't. Our job is to find Tommy. (point to the red steno) And why is that out?

dialogues.speaker: JUNIOR STEMMONS
dialogues.text: (like he's caught) I'm making notes separate from- (gear change off my glare) -I thought we were investigating Magdalena's disappearance-

dialogues.speaker: ME
dialogues.text: -Don't write shit down. What do you         * need Kid? A little bouncing ball,           * bottom of the screen?                       * (brace him harder) Magdalena is twenty years dirty with this Department...do you think         * a word of that exists on paper?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And there's reasons. Respect them.                      * Junior tucks the steno away, chastened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now we need surveillance set up on the house and revolving tails on both Madge and Lucille Magdalena. Their alibi is they were in Santa Barbara when Hector vanished. Find out if that's real. The tails and the stakeout start tonight. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you manage this? Junior jacks his chin just high enough to save face, tuck that steno away, this X-Ray stare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, Lieutenant.                                       *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rolling. Crenshaw south. Darktown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Police blotter gets me bupkis. Buzz                     * dispatch. Looking for license hits                      * on that `32 Ford Deuce. Nothing.                        * Zoom Darktown again. Zilch. Tommy                       * dug in deep.                                            * Startle, check my watch: 7:17 pm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cruise in, crossing the hangar to Pete.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Howard Hughes. Billionaire germ freak. Boob man. Pete's prime benefactor. Nobody had seen him in years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ME (V.O.) (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now he only communicated through a small standing army of lapdog lawyers he kept on staff. A small, effete blonde man: GEOFFREY MILTEER extends his hand, plastic-cordial, rubbed raw from waiting... MILTEER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gregory Milteer. Attorney-at-Law. A pleasure Lt. Klein. ME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave. Sorry I'm late.                                  * MILTEER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indeed. (motions to sit) Please. We sit at a huge drafting table. I shoot a sidelong to Pe MILTEER (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for your time on a Sunday. ME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a wink for Pete) Where's Mr. Hughes? MILTEER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unavailable. Unfortunately. But I've been given full authority to- ME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -I'm not contagious...if that's what he's worried about. Pete hate scowls me: have your fun, Asshole... MILTEER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't find that the least bit humorous Lt. Klein. ME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes you do. What's your pitch Mr.                      * Milteer? Milteer looks at Pete. Pete half-shrugs. Back to me now:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MILTEER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An `Actress' named Glenda Bledsoe signed a Service Contract that she's now willfully violating by acting in a Z-grade horror picture presently `shooting' in Griffith Park. Despite entreaties for her to cease participation in this absurdity, she continues to revel in her outlaw status with us. Thus we would like her destroyed. ME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What makes you think I can do a better job than your people? MILTEER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Bondurant says you're one of the smarter people he knows- ME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -dubious honor if you knew the other people Pete knows. (beat) So you want to catch her in violation of her Service Contract? Something like that? MILTEER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly. The morality clause in particular as the damage to her reputation would be most devastating: Nymphomaniac, Criminal, Communist...anything along these lines. Once you visit the set of her `Attack of the Atomic Vampires,' you'll see the void that is her character. We haven't a photograph handy, but she's playing the lead female role.         * ME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm happy to help. But my price is $10,000. Not 5. Pete laughs out loud. Milteer goes frigid. MILTEER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: $10,000 should buy more than help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For 10 give it any name you want. I'm a salaried employee of LAPD,                      * that means I'll have to find time off hours to do this. A long, cold moment drags...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agreed. Start tonight. Someone's                      * been stealing groceries from our talent domiciles. There's no proof that it's her, but it's her. Peter will provide you addresses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (faux fey)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you Peter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We look forward to your updates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dialing the Station:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sergeant, pass a message to Stemmons: I want him to meet me at the one-thousand block of South Tremaine tonight at 11 and at some point between now and then, I'll need him to do a preliminary work- up on a woman named Glenda Bledsoe. (beat, check spelling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: B-L-E-D-S-O-E. Thanks. I hang up, step out, yawn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two-fisting coffees. On top of a hill overlooking the `At Vampires' shoot. Pure schlock. The spaceship: a totaled Cadillac replete with home-made canopy and cardboard extensions on the fins. Crew: homeless winos. Extras: homeless drug-fiends. Scan the assembled `talent'...and s HER. My black and white picture. The Beauty at the fight. starlet I threw a Hail Mary dinner pass to at Bethune's victory party: GLENDA BLEDSOE. Emerging from a small trai

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twice in a day doesn't happen. Not in a city like LA. Not like this. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is fate. This is Cupid firing his whole fucking quiver. Move. Make sure she's real. HER laughing. Melodic. I hike down through the bramble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walk past a pair of beat Airstream Clippers. Watch her propping up this silver-haired junkie. She grabs a sound blanket, drapes him, hands him her coffee before siting d next to another Woman and rehearsing. I eyeball the rest of the `set.' Winos in werewolf masks capes, holding wooden ray-guns spray-painted silver: One pisses, bottle in one hand, cigarette/dick in the other. The "Director" is a fey manic, fingering a snuff-box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the big Armada landing, so I need everybody's energy up, up up! Where's my Alien Commander? The Pissing WEREWOLF careens back to set, pulling at his zipper, mask askew, covering his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT HERE GOD DAMN IT.
dialogues.text: MICKEY COHEN, 62, former mob boss. He boils eggs on a hot plate and slings hash to extras lining plywood picnic tab

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mickey Cohen: one-time LA crime kingpin and West Coast Mob heavy who now trawls for loose change. Winos vibe LAPD, make a hole as I approach:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil B. Demoted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where Klein goes tsuris follows. This is what I hate about being down, lip from the likes of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If this is `down' I never want to see `out.' How the mighty have fallen. MICKEY COHEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gives it right back) Which one of us are you talking about Klein? Word is the Federal Bureau is all hot and bothered with you Gonif. Hey, I hear J. Edgar schtups his personal assistant and makes him wear ladies hose. ME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What else are you hearing? MICKEY COHEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That this Welles Noonan character has developed quite a crush. That you might want to consider relocating to Dogdick, Delaware. ME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Been a marked man for years Mick. MICKEY COHEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the bullseye on your back's never been quite so big...if you need a new line of work, I got this faygele leading man needs replacing- -follow Mickey's gaze over to ROCK ROCKWELL. Buff McMan M the guy with Glenda at the Bethune party. He's primping w other boys decked in surplus SS uniforms, checking the si mirror of one of the `Alien craft' before his big close-u MICKEY COHEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His agent told me he could play straight. ME                                          *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His agent lied.                                       * MICKEY COHEN                                *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You interested?                                       * ME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. But I am interested in your                       * leading lady. Bradley sent me. Saw                    * her at the Bethune-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -not a chance. I'm still trying to play hide the submarine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want Chief Bradley angry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten years ago I could call for that                   * little Pisher's head on a stick. (looks around)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now the only thing you're putting on sticks are corn dogs. What's her name, Mick?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glenda.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still looking for HER)                           *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why was she there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Low-budget strategy: I send Glenda and Rock to any event where there's cameras -- Glenda gets guest-a'- honor treatment everywhere with that shape a' her's...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What she drive?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Following the tail-lights of a 56 Corvette. Top-down, whipping Blond hair split-second visible under passing st lights. Glenda pulls into what I guess is her place: tiny tidy Glendale flat. I roll past: no eye contact. Around the block. Park on the next street over. Waiting u I think of what comes next...get out now...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up to a fence. Scratch it: make sure a nuts-hungry Pooch isn't slobbering on the other side. Nothing. Vault the fe Dodge a pool. Over another fence and into-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -creep to a window: curtains pulled. Creep to another: th she is. Watch her: elegant fingers emanate from hands onl now beginning to betray age. Watch her shake her sandals Arranging three coffee cups on a tray: company coming. On cue: another car. A `53 Cadillac: the Director and Roc Rockwell. I crane my neck to get as much of her as I can. leaves the tray, cups steaming. Muffled greetings. Check window, open. Slide it up gentle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glenda clearing seats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coffee's in the kitchen. Let's go over this quick because I'm beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're set on a place where we can stash you and Rock. It's in Topanga Canyon, two weeks-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (petulant)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -two weeks? My body'll fall apart-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -think of it as 14 days of push-ups- (to the Director)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure about this Sid? Seems shaky. Was this Mickey's idea?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I think it's brilliant! Inspired! The two leads of Mickey Cohen's magnum opus get kidnapped! The press'll eat it up! They'll write about `Gangster Mickey,' the glory days. Couple a' headlines like that and interest in Atomic Vampires will go through the roof! (to Glenda)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's gonna grab you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A charmer I knew in another life...George Ainge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pat myself down for a pen, scribble on my hand: "A-I-N-G-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he okay with making it look real-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -he can't hit me in the face!                         * That's a deal-breaker!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll be thrilled to knock me around. Plus he's holding something of mine, so we can kill two birds. He'll grab us Tuesday in front of the Pacific Dining Car.                               *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about Hughes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about him? That angle can only help us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm dying to know...was he the Spruce Goose between the sheets?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My face folds up -- jealous-sour frown. I reach in, steal of the steaming cups, bolt. Audible as I retreat:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hung like a newborn and he called my tits `propellers.' Belly laughter from inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The real howler: fake kidnappings always bomb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parked. Tepid pulls off the stolen mug. Done. Toss it to passenger side: lands on a bed of crumpled Styrofoam. Loo up: the Magdalena residence looms a few doors down. Glanc the passenger seat: an envelope lined with fifty $100 bil The name: BLEDSOE written across the front. Pick it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thinking I could tip Milteer off to the kidnap plot and pick up the other half of my payment... (stare at that money)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
